concept.title: Page numbering in page layout documents
concept.shortdesc: A single page number sequence through an entire page layout document generated from DITA is often preferable to the traditional system of different page number sequences for front matter and back matter.

conbody.p: Traditional page numbering systems for printed documents have different numbering ranges for front matter, body content, and back matter. For example, the front matter (such as the Table of Contents, List of Figures, and Acknowledgements) might be numbered in lower case Roman numerals, with the page numbers restarting for the main body content in Arabic numerals.

The historical reasons for the different numbering sequences trace back to the production processes where the Table of Contents couldn't be created until the body of the document was paginated. Technology has since removed that limitation, but in general, the traditional numbering system has persisted.

When creating PDF (or similar page layout) output documents where the intention is that the documents will primarily be read on-screen, you should process the document with a single page numbering sequence. This will make it easier for the document to be navigated, when the actual page numbers in the viewer match the page numbers displayed on the pages in the document.

section.title: Rationale
section.p: Bob Doyle summarised a discussion on the Yahoo! DITA Users Group about page numbering as follows: Traditional books use lower-case Roman numerals for introductory front material. This and folio-style chapter numbering, page 2-35, are deprecated practices today.

If PDF files are numbered with arabic numerals starting from the title page, they are much easier to view on-line, especially when the source has not or is unable to add hyperlinks from page references in the ToC, LoF, LoT, Index, and cross-references. At least you can then "Go to page" and be confident of arriving at the correct destination, instead of having to apply an offset to account for the 8 pp (or whatever) of roman-numbered frontmatter, or going to the trouble to massage the PDF file so that both roman and arabic page numbers can be used as "Go to page" targets. My question is "Why perpetuate a hangover from 19th century book printing whose rationale has long disappeared?" When books were set in hot metal, compositors typically started making up the type of the body of the book into arabic-numbered pages so that the editor could work off the page proofs to compile a table of Contents, list of Figures, list of Tables, Index, and replace the page-number placeholders of cross-references with the actual number. This also allowed the compositor to work more efficiently by doing something while the Preface and Introduction were being written by, respectively, a Famous Person and the Author. The bastard title, title page, imprint (copyright, legals, credits, etc.) and ToC, LoF, LoT, etc. were also typeset at this time. After all this frontmatter was typeset, proofed, and revised, it too was made up into pages. Now there was a bunch of pages that preceded page 1, so they were numbered in lower-case roman, I, ii, iii, iv, etc. With ToC, etc, xrefs, Index entries, etc. now able to be regenerated in minutes, there is no longer any need to number frontmatter in roman and the body in arabic. In fact, with PDF being the medium now used to submit camera art to printers, emailed to reviewers, etc., there are far more reasons to number straight through in arabic from the first to the last page. So don't bother. Here endeth the sermon.
